title: Hoover® Air™ Pro UH72450: Shutting Off?
description:
Hi Anna! I read your review on Hoover.com about your Air Pro shutting off during use and put together this quick video with some tips that should help. If you have any more questions or concerns, please let us know. Thanks!

-Ian
Hoover Customer Care

Lin

asset.author: Hoover
asset.hookText:
Hi Anna! I read your review on Hoover.com about your Air Pro shutting off during use and put together this quick video with some tips that should help. If you have any more questions or concerns, please let us know. Thanks!

-Ian
Hoover Customer Care

Link to this video: https://youtu.be/XeeXJlSQdMw

transcripts: Hi Ana this is Ian from Hoover. I saw your review on Hoover dot com I want to give you some tips on how to prevent your air pro from overheating. If your suction power has steadily diminished that usually indicates that there could be one or more clogs that have built up in your air path. That's an easy fix. Here's what to do first detach your dirt cup and twist off the lid to access your filter. Pull out your filter and check its underside here. If it looks dirty. Run it under warm water and let it dry on its edge for 24 hours. Even if you regularly rinse it placing a filter that's not fully dry back into your canister could clog your filter. Next check your lower hose for clogs by removing it here. You should be able to visually inspect if there is a blockage. If there is a blockage you can remove it with a grabber tool like so. Next remove your air valve by pressing on these taps with your four fingers and pull it out like so. If there's anything jammed in there you can tap the debris out into a wastebasket if you're still overheats on area rugs. Try turning this air valve dial to the r in floor to slightly reduce suction and allow air to pass through the vacuum. Let us know if you need more help via Facebook, Twitter or email me directly at. In that McCormick at floor care dot com.
